description-en: This image from the Oriental Calender Manufacturing Company shows a woman, wearing western clothes, preparing tean and snacks. In the background, an opened window with a view towards the mountains can be seen. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This image, depicting a woman leaning over a tea table spread with a china tea service, flowers in a vase, and snacks, reminds us that that comfort was carefully designed, rather than left to chance. Here the shapes of the flowers in the vase are repeated in the pattern of the table-cloth, while the framed landscape hanging on the wall itself echoes the real vista visible out the open window. The woman herself looks as if she is posing for a picture: she certainly has prepared her appearance carefully, with her sari worn in the westernized Parsi style, careful makeup, and modern haircut. Whether in the more urban space of the woman on the phone, or in the bucolic setting of the woman pouring tea in front of snow-clad mountains and workers plucking tea, the emphasis is not on architectural space or the social relationships of those who inhabit that space. Instead it is on the refined comforts of everyday life—a life to which, as Philip Lutgendorf’s essay “Chai Why?” shows, the consumption of tea has become a central ritual. Here struggles over basic necessities or the labor of the tea pickers in the distance have been replaced with lighter amusements and more cultured achievements. (Abigail McGowan)(gs)
